Award.AwardTitle: Arithmetic 2015: Elliptic Curves, Diophantine Geometry, and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the international conference "Arithmetic 2015: Elliptic Curves, Diophantine Geometry, and Dynamics" to be held at Brown University in Providence, RI from August 11 - 15, 2015. The conference will bring together experts, young researchers, and graduate students working in the broadly-defined areas of arithmetic geometry and number theory. It will provide an opportunity for graduate students and young researchers to interact with leading experts and to learn about recent results. The conference is expected to attract approximately 200 participants. It will feature 23 distinguished invited speakers along with a poster session highlighting the work of graduate students and recent Ph.D.s. The grant will support the participation of approximately 30 graduate students and young faculty, as well as several of the invited speakers.

The study of elliptic curves, diophantine geometry, and arithmetic dynamics are all modern extensions of the classical, even ancient, study of integer solutions to polynomial equations. Among the many important concepts in the field, two principal ideas lie close to the heart of all three topics: the study of rational points on algebraic varieties, and the theory of arithmetic height functions. The conference will foster collaboration across these different areas of arithmetic geometry and number theory by focusing on these two unifying themes. More information can be found at the conference website http://math.colorado.edu/arithmetic2015/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arithmetic 2015 conference was held from Tuesday, August 11 through Saturday, August 15, 2015, at Brown University in Providence, RI. The conference brought together experts, young researchers and graduate students in number theory, with a particular emphasis on elliptic curves, rational points on abelian varieties, Diophantine geometry, and arithmetic dynamics. Number theory has a long history as one of the central topics of research in mathematics, but it remains a thriving field today, and these four subfields have seen exciting growth in recent years. Elliptic curves are special algebraic equations whose sets of solutions have beautiful and useful arithmetic properties. Abelian varieties are generalizations of elliptic curves to higher dimensions, and there are even more open questions about their sets of rational points. Diophantine geometry is the study of arithmetic height functions, approximation of irrational numbers by rationals, and other powerful tools that have proven very useful in the study of rational points and much more. Finally, arithmetic dynamics is the number-theoretic study of dynamical systems formed by repeatedly composing an algebraic function with itself. The four topics are intimately and intricately related, and the conference provided a stimulating setting for researchers in these areas to share their expertise and generate new interactions.

The conference had 168 participants from around the country and the world. It featured 23 talks over five days: twelve 60-minute talks by plenary speakers, and eleven 45-minute invited speakers. In addition, 30 graduate students presented their work at a well-attended two-hour poster session on Wednesday, August 12.

The talks, posters, and opportunities for interaction led to a great deal of collaboration and discussion, including extended conversations between graduate students and established experts at the poster session. Besides the speakers, NSF funding helped provide travel support for 50 graduate students and recent PhDs, making attendance possible for many more young researchers than would otherwise have been the case.
